SUMMARY: l-idonate regulator, IdnR, is a transcription factor that regulates genes involved in l-idonate metabolism, which are organized in two coordinately regulated transcription units [9658018, 14973046]. This regulator is positively autoregulated and co-regulates with CRP, a global transcriptional regulator; se regulators bind cooperatively to activate transcription of an operon related to transport and catabolism of l-idonate [14973046]. Synsis of this operon is induced when Escherichia coli is grown on l-idonate/5KG in absence of glucose and gluconate. In addition, this regulator represses transcription of genes related to gluconate metabolism [9658018]. In presence of l-idonate, IdnR binds to 16-nucleotide-long DNA-target sites in idnK/idnDOTR intergenic region to coordinately activate transcription of idnKp and idnDp [14973046]. IdnR exhibits a high similarity to GntR (53%) and belongs to LacI/GalR family of transcriptional regulators [11115104]. It is part of idnDOTR operon, yet it can also be transcribed as an independent (idnR) transcription unit [14973046].
